0.text:
Welcome to the Neuro-Cognitive Simulator.
Are you ready to map your decision-making style?

1.text:
CONCEPT: Uncertainty Management
You are in a new city. Do you stick to a strict 
GPS route (A) or wander to see what you find (B)?

2.text:
CONCEPT: Prediction Error
The GPS leads to a dead end. Do you wait for a 
recalc (A) or immediately try a manual detour (B)?

16.text:
CONCEPT: Model Reliability
The GPS is still loading. Do you continue to 
trust the system (A) or give up and ask a local 
for a landmark (B)?

3.text:
CONCEPT: Social Exploitation
You see a crowd at a local venue. Do you go inside 
because it is clearly popular (A) or keep looking 
for a hidden spot no one has found yet (B)?

15.text:
CONCEPT: Reward Validation
Inside, the music is loud but the food smells great. 
Do you stay because the reward is guaranteed (A) 
or leave to find a quieter, unknown option (B)?

12.text:
CONCEPT: Information Search
While wandering, do you stay to watch a street 
performer (A) or look for a quiet map of the area (B)?

13.text:
CONCEPT: Internal vs. External Cues
You feel lost. Do you look for a physical landmark 
(A) or use previous knowledge of the city layout (B)?

4.text:
CONCEPT: Model-Based Learning
When learning a new hobby, do you read the full 
manual (A) or learn by making mistakes (B)?

14.text:
CONCEPT: Resource Allocation
Your detour is taking longer than expected. Do you 
stop for a break (A) or push through to the end (B)?

5.text:
CONCEPT: Sensory Hierarchy
When looking at a painting, do you see the 
overall mood (A) or the tiny brushstrokes (B)?

6.description: You prioritize 'Social Exploitation'—using established signals to guarantee a reward. Daily Example: Checking reviews before trying a new place.

7.description: You prioritize 'Information Gain'—seeking new data even if it risks a bad experience. Daily Example: Buying a mystery-flavored snack just to try it.

8.description: You rely on internal frameworks (Previous Knowledge) to minimize uncertainty. Daily Example: Using a recipe as a guide but trusting your 'gut' on seasoning.

9.description: You build understanding from raw sensory data and direct experience. Daily Example: Assembling furniture without looking at the instructions.

10.description: Your brain prioritizes high-level perceptual hierarchies, focusing on 'The Big Picture'. Daily Example: Recognizing a song by its beat before the lyrics start.

11.description: You focus on 'mechanistic fidelity'—the fine details of how things work. Daily Example: Noticing a specific font used on a website.
